definition: the final (of a syllable) (Chinese phonology)/rhyme/appeal/charm/(literary) pleasant sound

sentences.english: Following these rhymes, comes that valuable section of prose material which is generally called experience stories.
sentences.chinese: 韵语之后，是颇为可观的散文部分“生活故事”。

sentences.english: The second part it is the rhyme one that is specialized in.
sentences.chinese: 第二部分是对《列女传》韵语的专门研究。

sentences.english: Did you seek the civilian's peaceful and languishing rhymes?
sentences.chinese: 你寻求过老百姓的和平而忧伤的韵语吗？

definition: poetic form consisting of four lines of five syllables, with rhymes on first, second and fourth line
regular verse/strict poetic form with eight lines of 5, 6 or 7 syllables and even lines rhyming

notes on poetry, an essay genre consisting of informal commentary on poems and poets and their lives (old)/a genre of narrative literature interspersing prose with poetry, popular in the Tang and Song dynasties
pausing at the end of a phrase or sentence (in former times, before punctuation marks were used)/punctuation/periods and commas/sentences and phrases
to interpret and make glossaries and commentaries on classic texts
old language/the Classics/Classical Chinese as a literary model, esp. in Tang and Song prose/Classical Chinese as a school subject
level and oblique tones (technical term for Classical Chinese rhythmic poetry)
